tweet: From @Nextgov: #arpae bill will increase the office’s funding by $27 million annually over the next five years,  topping out at $500 million in 2024. READ MORE: https://www.nextgov.com/policy/2019/07/republican-lawmaker-proposes-increased-funding-energys-darpa/158726/ …

Galloway went on to become a leader in space policy, serving at multiple organizations and receiving a variety of awards. You can read more about her accomplishments here:  https://www.nasa.gov/topics/history/features/galloway_obit.html …

President Eisenhower signed the bill into law, creating @NASA, which replaced the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA).  NASA officially opened on Oct. 1, 1958. pic.twitter.com/XpblQpSzBn

Galloway helped draft the legislation. Per @NASA, "Galloway successfully lobbied to designate the new organization an Administration rather than an Agency to give it broader authority to coordinate with many other government agencies." https://www.nasa.gov/specials/signing/ …

After Eisenhower proposed creating NASA as a civilian agency, the House and Senate drafted bills to create NASA as a civilian space agency overseeing the U.S. space program. pic.twitter.com/fJUYLwFpNJ

Galloway worked for the Congressional Research Service and has said, "The only thing I knew about outer space at that time was that the cow had jumped over the Moon."  https://www.nasa.gov/topics/history/features/galloway_obit.html …
She wrote a report titled "The Problems of Congress in Formulating Outer Space Legislation" that summarized Congressional testimony and presented policy options for managing the U.S. space program.

After Sputnik launched in 1957 Congress convened hearings on the U.S. space program. Then-Senator Lyndon B. Johnson asked Galloway to serve as the Special Consultant to the Senate Special Committee on Space & Astronautics, formulating questions for witnesses & analyzing testimony

Maybe you knew that #OTD in 1958 President Eisenhower signed the National Aeronautics and Space Act, officially creating @NASA. But how much do you know about Eilene Galloway, the Congressional staffer who was instrumental in researching and writing the law? #womeninstem pic.twitter.com/5ycOrCf2bU

What is #sustainablechemistry? According to @USGAO : Sustainability may refer to economic, environmental, or social sustainability. Achieving all three—a concept known as the “triple bottom line”—has become a goal of some businesses, including many in the chemical industry.

DYK: the chemical manufacturing industry employed more than 858,000 people in June 2019 and the Department of Commerce estimated that the sector generated an additional 2.7 million indirect jobs via industry suppliers.

.@RogerPielkeJr Through establishing the context within which expert advice is provided, policymakers also have an important role to play in securing scientific integrity...Advisors advise, decision makers decide.

.@RogerPielkeJr : It is essential to distinguish science advice from policy advice, and both types of advice should fall under scientific integrity policies. FULL TESTIMONY:  https://republicans-science.house.gov/sites/republicans.science.house.gov/files/2019-07-17%20Testimony%20Pielke.pdf …
Recognize that science does not speak with one voice, differences of opinion are normal and to be expected

Hold those formal, authoritative advisory bodies to the highest standards of scientific
integrity (e.g., in committee balance, management of conflicts of interest, focus on well-defined questions, acknowledgement of diversity of views, etc.)

GOP witness @RogerPielkeJr: For both science advice and policy advice, utilize and defend established, authoritative mechanisms for securing expert advice, such as through FACA committees, the National Academy of Sciences or legislatively mandated assessments;

GOP witness @RogerPielkeJr: In cases where policy advice is desired, clarify requests to experts for support for proposed policies from requests for a discussion of alternative options that might be used to achieve a policy objective

GOP witness @RogerPielkeJr: 5 suggestions for how elected & appointed officials can contribute to scientific integrity. 
1. In cases where science advice is desired, ask clear questions that are answerable using the tools of science.
